106368: Molimo, Maro-Sorcerer.author: Fanaticmogg
106368: Molimo, Maro-Sorcerer.text_parsed:
Back in Tenth, they printed two legendary creatures for each color. They were all fairly simple, generally not incredibly powerful but still good enough to be gems in new players' casual decks. Take Molimo: Cool ability which fits well with Green's land-getting abilities, but really just a big, strong beatstick. A fun card and good way to learn the power of Terror.

Nowadays we're seen quite a few legends that are designed to either act as EDH Generals or to go straight into competitive decks. Whether that's a good or bad thing (or even a new thing) is another discussion, for another day.

106384: Reya Dawnbringer.author: KnightLord77
106384: Reya Dawnbringer.text_parsed:
BEAUTIFUL ARTWORK!!! And I was so glad to see that they had the same artist who did the card's original artwork do the artwork again for its reprint! Matthew D. Wilson is truly talented!

As far as the card's functionality and playability, it's a little overpriced, but worth it. Besides, by the time you are able to play Reya Dawnbringer, you will more than likely have a number of creature cards in your graveyard that are worth bringing back to the battlefield. It would be nice if her Power were at least 5, though.

106384: Reya Dawnbringer.author: BegleOne
106384: Reya Dawnbringer.text_parsed:
The problem with Reya is that in a reanimation deck, it's always better to reanimate the kill card directly, rather than reanimating Reya and letting her resurrect your kill card a turn later.

I propose the following solutions to the problem:

Reya the Epic - {6}{W}{W}{W}
Creature- Angel - 4/6
Flying, Protection from CMC 2 and less
At the beginning of your upkeep, return ALL creatures from your graveyard to the battlefield.
If Reya would be put into a graveyard, exile Reya instead.

Reya the Titan - {6}{W}{W}{W}
Creature- Angel - 4/6
Flying, Indestructible
When Reya enters the battlefield or attacks, return target creature from your graveyard to the battlefield.

Reya the Renewer - {6}{W}{W}{W}
Creature- Angel - 4/6
Flying, Vigilance
When you cast Reya, destroy all creatures. They can't be regenerated. Then return all creatures from all graveyards to the battlefield under your control.
All creatures you control are white. If a creature is placed into the graveyard from the battlefield, instead return it to the battlefield under your control.

106384: Reya Dawnbringer.text_parsed:
I love the artwork for both the reprint and the original (I have the Invasion version) and appreciate that Mr. Wilson did the reprint artwork as well.

I like to get this into play early through a simple Wild Mongrel or Tireless Tribe discard --> Breath of Life, and then keep discarding creatures through the Mongrel/Tribe, bringing them back through Reya. In a G/W angel/fatty deck, this can be very effective when it works out.
It's simple, but effective.

106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.author: Temple_Garden
106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.text_parsed:
Great for a burn deck. You can usually clear the board with burn before dropping him (especially now that Earthquake is back) and if you can't you can always use him to help remove any trouble creatures once he is in play. A creature that casts Lightning Bolt each turn is hard to beat, especially when you have your own burn to back it up. If the board is clear, then swing for six. Since the return of Lightning Bolt, anything with less than four toughness is going to be removed by burn fairly easily.

It's also cool they reprinted him in the same core set along with Phage the Untouchable. All they needed to do was reprint Akroma, Angel of Wrath instead of Cho-Manno, Revolutionary and the old party crew would have been back together.

106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.text_posted: I agree that Kamahl is very similar to Arcanis, but I would much rather have a free Ancestral Recall than a lightning bolt, and if you are thinking about Old abilities attached to Pitfighter legends, then we are missing Healing Salve, Giant Growth, and Dark Ritual.

106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.author: CorkBulb
106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.text_parsed:
Kamahl is my hero! First off, he is essentially a reuseable lightning bolt every turn, and if you've burned all of your opponent's creatures the previous turn you play him, he can be a reusable Ball Lightning! (without trample, oh well)

Kamahl is awesome and has been my reliable finisher for my mono-red burn/aggro deck. However, he does have some downsides:

#1-The 1 toughness really sucks, especially with lack of trample or first strike. It *is* very embarrassing for Kamahl, Super Barbarian Hero who fought Dominaria's greatest villains (with that huge sword and armor) to be taken down by 2 Little Girls >_<
#2-He is expensive to play, I often pray for that 6th mountain
#3-He is legendary, but since he screams "REMOVE ME ***NOW***", having more than one in your hand is usually a good thing, and the expression on your opponent's face when you re-cast another one the next turn after he *just* burnt him is priceless, especially if your opponent is open for the 6.

Kamahl wound be *Godlike* and easily 5-stars if he had either of the following:

#1-First strike, like his sister, Jeska. That's not cool that that big man's sister can straight up kill him in a fight. Even her ability can kill him! At least with first strike it would take fourteen Little Girls to kill him, and fifteen if he tapped one off! (How funny and sick would it be to see Kamahl chopping down a line of 14 little girls?) That seems more appropriate though...
#2-At least 1 extra toughness. Then he could at least survive a freakin hornet sting! (maybe he's deathly allergic, anyone think of that?)
#3-Trample. Then at least he could suicide win you if he had to chop through some creatures for a glory attack.
#4-Cost Less. Then he can start smashing those Wellwishers a turn earlier!

Anyway, I can dream all day. He is what he is. 4.5/5 stars for usefulness. And I love that art. I certainly wouldn't want him after me! And that flavor text runs chills up my spine.

106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.author: Tiggurix
106398: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.text_parsed:
The Crab Umbra was made for this guy, pretty much.
Imagine this situation: You've just begun your turn with a Kamahl, Pit Fighter on the board enchanted with a Crab Umbra, while your opponent's got Grizzly Bears and Wild Griffin on his side of the table. You skip your main phase since you've got no cards in your hand at the moment, and go on straight to the combat phase. Before you declare attackers you tap Kamahl and kill his Griffin, and then you pay (2)(U) to activate the Umbra's ability and untap Kamahl. You then proceed to tap Kamahl once again and kill his Bears, and then you activate the Umbra for the second time, untap Kamahl, and finally proceed to go on to swing for 6 with Kamahl on your opponent. So in the end you paid (4)(U)(U) to gain board advantage and seriously damage your opponent, all while Kamahl was hidden safely behind the Umbra's Totem Armor. Sounds like a good deal to me.

@Three_Toe: Those were just some random creatures I thought off to prove a point.

106405: Mirri, Cat Warrior.author: patronofthesound
106405: Mirri, Cat Warrior.text_parsed:
This is a very controlling card for green, and the synergy between her abilities and general green buffing is remarkable. She is an incredible early (and late if pumped) game defender, and most importantly, she almost always nudges some damage through.

That forestwalk is also not to be underestimated. I think about 40% of players on magic online use green in edh (edric, animar, zegana, azusa, doran, mimeoplasm all quite popular right now) so she turns into a remove-or-die situation pretty quick. This is less relevant in person, where if your friends play green you might seem a bit nasty using her. I highly recommend her as a general, although beware, monogreen edh is a very tough but rewarding deckbuilding experience. I have gotten great results with her though, and a simple GDW strategy laced with equips and monogreen's sparse removal choices. ( hornet sting, roots, moonglove, etc.) If they're playing green, I get a huge advantage, and I switch to an aggressive commander damage strategy. Occasionally I can pull off a fifth turn win:

1 llanowar elves
2 mirri
3 increasing savagery, swing for 7
4 swing for 7
5 swing for 7. You just lost to forestwalk.

Although, a 6-9 turn win is much more common. Silhana ledgewalker makes a great second in command, she responds very well to stacking equips/auras.

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: gongshowninja
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed:
Very cool, art, 5/5 for that.

Not bad for a blue card, either. I've always hated blue. Taking delight in playing cards on your opponent's turn and not letting them resolve a single spell on theirs reeks of sociopathy, but I digress. Card draw is solid, for sure, and is indicative of blue's nigh-overwhelming strength of the time.

This point brings me to my next. A lot of blue players I know are quick to cry that white is now overpowered, and that blue has "died".

Yeah. Okay.

A lot of people forget that white was weak for a long time before the Shards block, when I believe the power creep began (Elspeth vs. Tezzeret). Look at the "boon" cycle- Ancestral Recall vs. Healing Salve. Which one is on the Power 9? Hint: not the white one.

All I'm saying is that blue isn't dead. It lost a lot of awesome cards, yes. Even I can appreciate Cryptic Command. Arcanis, above, rocks. But white getting Baneslayer (which is a pretty broken card for its cost, and in my opinion, should have been more balanced) and Elspeth does not mean that white is a good colour, nor does it mean that blue has died. Pass this on to those that play either colour, and maybe it'll put things into perspective.

Sorry for kinda ranting.

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: TheWrathofShane
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed: Hes not overpowered at all. He costs 6 cmc so unless your playing with ramp in a blue heavy deck, hes sitting in your hand for a while. His "defensive" ability costs 4. When he hits the board, your opponent either has a nuke and deals with it, or they don't. And if they don't, that obviously means they have no way of dealing with this monster. So his 2nd ability is really just top deck defense. Yeah you could throw a lightning grieve on him, but then if they have a nuke they could nuke him before its attached. Hes the blue equivalent to Force of Nature (speaking in terms of old). Either you had an answer or you lost the game.

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: ManInRed
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed:
The Omnipotent Combo: Arcanis the Omnipotent + Mind Over Matter + Library of Leng

The most powerful combo in all of Magic. Once it is out you can rearrange all the cards in your hand and library in any order you wish; untap any artifact, land, or creature you control an infinite number of times, and tap any artifact, land, or creature your opponents control an infinite number of times. Short of your opponent drawing Crash, its checkmate.

If you have an Island: you got infinite mana. If you got Prodigal Sorcerer, you can deal infinite damage among any number of targets you choose as many times as you choose. If you got a Patron Wizard, you can counter any number of spells unless the cast pays an infinite amount of mana as many times as you choose. Though with all their land constantly tapped, your opponent will have trouble even paying 1 mana. A Wall of Kelp can summon an infinite number of creatures, turning a Beast of Burden into an infinity/infinity creature. Of course at this point, you're just showing off.

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: Hermeezey
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed:
Pro-tip: the more cards you draw, the higher chance you have of winning.

Factor in the fact that blue is all about counter and countrol, trading card-for-card against your opponent and those three extra cards suddenly become game changing. Not to mention that blue is naturally a slow, reactive, and defensive archetype so stalling until you have enough mana for Arcanis should have been pre-built into most Control decks anyway. More importantly, I usually would never tap-out and throw Arcanis out there without protection.

The only real downside to Arcanis is it cost 4-mana to bounce him back to safety. Not to mention since combat damage doesn't stack like it did in onslaught, the effect loses some of its versatility. Even after you save Arcanis, you have to sink another 6-mana to drop him again and wait another turn before you can start tapping for cards, which drastically slows down the tempo if you are trying to come from behind or racing a tight clock. If his ability cost UU instead of 2UU, it would have been much more playable. Or if it was 2UU for a phase out effect. But I guess in the end, you just have to play smart with him. If you can't, then maybe you shouldn't be playing Blue-control anyways.

@Maninred

That combo doesn't work. Library of Leng makes effects that force you to discard put those cards to the top of the library. The discard aspect of Mind Over Matter is a cost and is therefore unaffected.

Of course, Arcanis and MoM together is semi infinite draw, and the only reason it's semi infinite is because of deck size. Include one elixir of immortality and suddenly you've got an infinite life, infinite draw, infinite mana combo.

I feel sorry for whatever unsuspecting player tries to remove Arcanis from play.

Player A: I cast doom blade, targeting Arcanis
Player B: In response.....

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: flare1122
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed:
Honestly think that if WOTC really wanted to make an omnipotent wizard they should have made him better then this. Blue is only one color you still have four more I think arcanis should have been the first 5 CMC 5 color hybrid with a five powerful abilities one for each color.

Example could be:
1U tap: Draw 3 cards, each oppenent puts the top card of his/her library into their graveyard for twice the amount of cards drawn this way.
XB tap: Search your graveyard and deck for a nonland permanent with converted mana cost X or less and put it on the battlefield, you lose life equal to 1.5 times the amount of X rounded up.
2W tap: Name 2 colors or colorless (can be any combination of 2 colors or 1 color and colorless) permanents you control gain protection from chosen color (or colorless) until the beginnig of your next turn.
4G tap: Creatures you control get +3/+3 and trample until end of turn. If any creature where to die this turn put 1/1 green saproling creature tokens onto the battlefield under your control equal to that creature's power.
X XXR tap: For each time you paid the first X choose an opponent (each opponent can be chosen multiple times) each chosen opponent is dealt XX damage to them and each creature they control, copy this ability for each opponent that was chosen more than once for each time they were chosen.

Example could be:
1U tap: Draw 3 cards, each oppenent puts the top card of his/her library into their graveyard for twice the amount of cards drawn this way.
XB tap: Search your graveyard and deck for a nonland permanent with converted mana cost X or less and put it on the battlefield, you lose life equal to 1.5 times the amount of X rounded up.
2W tap: Name 2 colors or colorless (can be any combination of 2 colors or 1 color and colorless) permanents you control gain protection from chosen color (or colorless) until the beginnig of your next turn.
4G tap: Creatures you control get +3/+3 and trample until end of turn. If any creature where to die this turn put 1/1 green saproling creature tokens onto the battlefield under your control equal to that creature's power.
X XXR tap: For each time you paid the first X choose an opponent (each opponent can be chosen multiple times) each chosen opponent is dealt XX damage to them and each creature they control, copy this ability for each opponent that was chosen more than once for each time they were chosen.

106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.author: OlvynChuru
106426: Arcanis the Omnipotent.text_parsed: I have two possible theories about why he is called "omnipotent." One is that he is not omnipotent, and that is just what he is called (similar to how the flavor text for Eron the Relentless says that he is "immortal" even though he is not completely immortal). Perhaps Arcanis has so many abilities that no one has seen the full extent of his powers (considering that he can now draw over 14000 different cards), so characters feel like he can do so many things that he may very well be omnipotent (even if he isn't). The other theory is that he IS omnipotent, and he merely lends you a fraction of his power.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: JaxsonBateman
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Whilst the card does say play, the gatherer information has been updated to *cast*, meaning you have to pay the mana cost and put it onto the battlefield from your hand.

Whilst lots of 'instant win' cards have potential, realistically, the lack of shroud on most of them makes them sitting ducks, or they have such unrealistic expectations that you're likely to never pull them off (I've only ever 'instant won' twice myself - both casual times - the first in a multiplayer match where two Soul Wardens and everyone's creatures coming out gave me enough health for Felidar Sovereign to win it for me, and another where I was playing a Bant lifegaining deck (splashed with a little red), and Mayael's Aria + Cradle of Vitality + Wall of Reverence ended up comboing for the win (thanks to the opponent having pretty much no spot removal).

In terms of Phage, being black protects her from Terror/Doom Blade, and her toughness helps protect her from bolts, but she can still be removed. Protection from Black creatures such as White Knight will also block her indefinitely, saving the game for the other player.

In order to realistically win with her, you'd need something like Whispersilk Cloak or an instant/enchantment that provides Trample. But then, I'd expect her to be removed as soon as you put either of those on the stack. It'd be possible to catch your opponent by surprise in a game, throwing her out late when they're low on cards (and spot removal), but you can bet your bottom dollar they'd consider holding onto some if they knew she was around.

On the other hand, she could protect from certain effects and abilities like Telemin Performance or Liliana Vess' major (not that I've *ever* seen anyone actually get that far with her).

An interesting card, but likely to always be one of those "instant wins" that don't really work.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
@Erokow:
Hopefully this clears things up a bit... At the end of Odyssey block storyline, angry Kamahl stabbed his sister Jeska with his Mirari-enhanced sword, she didn't die but was brought back to power by the Cabal Patriarch as Phage. So yes she's undead, but with Akroma they make a red/green white black/red triangle (you forgot that Kamahl turned into a druid between Odyssey and Onslaught), and blue can be included if you consider Ixidor as part of that little group (which you should, since Akroma was born of his flesh), so the four of them represent all five colors, and bam you get Karona.

Also, I've lost to this card exactly one time. It was embarrassing. It should never be able to happen.

Just wondering if anyone else has noticed that after the Magic 2010 rule change Phage has become a card that isn't very useful.
First off she has to be cast so unless you reduce her man cost then it is kind of a waste.
Second after the new rules regarding combat damage Phage's second ability is also useless. Just asking did Wizards want to make her an expensive wort in the game.
Ok I admit this idea would probablyu make her broken on every account but it may have been a good idea to change that second ability to deathtouch so she would be of some use.
From what I can see unless Phage is given an evasion ability she's a target (an expensive one at that), the other option would be to increse her power and toughness but then again you might as well have a Festering Goblin which is a seventh of the mana cost.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Makasat
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed: thedeathscythe: This card doesn't work with Donate like you describe. First, you can only Momentary Blink creatures you control (which you will not if you donated your Phage), second, even if you use other flickering effects that allow you to flicker other players' creatures, like Glimmerpoint Stag, you will make Phage return under YOUR control and then lose the game yourself. So, to get the effect you are aiming for, you need to use a card like Endless Whispers: play Phage, sac it to something with Endless Whispers on the board, wait until Phage pops back under opponent's control at end of turn.
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_posted: thedeathscythe: This card doesn't work with [autocard]Donate[/autocard] like you describe. First, you can only [autocard]Momentary Blink[/autocard] creatures you control (which you will not if you donated your Phage), second, even if you use other flickering effects that allow you to flicker other players' creatures, like [autocard]Glimmerpoint Stag[/autocard], you will make Phage return under YOUR control and then lose the game yourself. So, to get the effect you are aiming for, you need to use a card like [autocard]Endless Whispers[/autocard]: play Phage, sac it to something with Endless Whispers on the board, wait until Phage pops back under opponent's control at end of turn.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Snafinturtle
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Looking at some of the turn 3 combos in the list... here's the poor man's version:

Turn 1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Cathodion
Turn 2: Mountain, Culling the Weak sacking Cathodion, Cast Phage, tap mountain, Reckless Charge or Crimson Wisps

Turn 2 Hastey Phage, and all it cost you was 1 creature, and your entire hand, luckily you're safe from Force Spike when casting Phage since you have the mountain.

Assuming they don't play a creature on their first turn (and you went first), they're open to be Swatted by Her, and judging by swat's art, it hurts :(

I'll admit though, you'd have to have pretty amazing luck to get all 7 cards in hand on turn 1 or 2, even with 4 copies of each in the deck.

Play a [autocard]Lotus Petal[/autocard].
Tap Swamp ([B]) to play a [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] ([B][B][B]).
[autocard]Entomb[/autocard] Phage in your graveyard for [B], then [autocard]Exhume[/autocard] her for [1][B] into play.

Wait a few seconds for your opponent to coll you a n00b and an idiot, then [autocard]Stifle[/autocard] her deadly cip with [U] from the Lotus Petal. :D

Turn 2: Kill!

And for the extra lucky not-going-first legendary eight card first turn kill combo engine:

Discard [autocard]Elvish Spirit Guide[/autocard] for [G] to play [autocard]Concordant Crossroads[/autocard].
OR
Discard [autocard]Simian Spirit Guide[/autocard] for [R] to play [autocard]Mass Hysteria[/autocard].
OR
Just use a second Lotus Petal if you're not playing with the Vintage restriction list.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: endersblade
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
This + Viridian Longbow = you're a moron. Pinging is not combat damage. Never has been, never will be.

About the best thing that can be done with her is making her unblockable, and there are a billion different ways to do that in just about any color. Besides, if your opponent finds out you're playing with this card, I'm sure they'll pull out any number of ways to get rid of her. Condemn ftw.

That being said, I've had so much fun blowing this card up in multiplayer it's not even funny anymore. Someone has already commented on dropping an O-ring on her, then disenchanting it. What's more fun is dropping the O-ring, and watch them cringe every time someone ends their turn, wondering which player is going to blow the ring up and make that player lose the game. There are just too many easy ways to make this card backfire to make it worth running, as well as too many ways to get rid of her. Thankfully, creature removal/counterspells are instant, and she is neither uncounterable nor has shroud. (Word to the wise: Whispersilk cloak is only good if you actually get the time to equip it, since equipping is sorcery speed.)

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Bobth
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
I was just reading the story about her. Apparently, she used to be a barbarian named Jeska, Warrior Adept. She was then captured by Braids, Cabal Minion, and turned into Phage by the Cabal Patriarch. Cursed to rot anything she touched, she could only wear clothes made of silk, and touch inorganic materials. However, the Patriarch could touch her, because he shared a similar curse, and they actually had a child. The child was the reincarnation of some sort of god that had been hanging out with the Cabal.

Eventually, Akroma, Angel of Wrath came to kill Phage (that was actually the purpose behind Akroma being created - she was created by an illusionist and is technically an ILLUSION angel), and the Patriarch killed her, but accidentally killed Phage and their child in the same swing, causing a new god to be born somehow (part of it was Phage's planeswalker spark) - called Karona, False God. Eventually, Karona died, but Phage's planeswalker spark kept her part of Karona alive. She was ressurected as Jeska (yay!). After a bunch of other stuff, Jeska sacrificed herself and all of her planeswalker powers to cause the Mending to happen, which was a major MtG event. I suggest you read more about all of this, I was new to the game and didn't know any of it, but I'm assuming a lot of the older players did, if the Mending was involved.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: DarthParallax
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
One of only two creatures left in old MAGIC cards that compares well to Post-Mythic Rarity Creatures.

"Little Bigs" Baneslayer Angel, Titans Wurmcoil Engine
"Big Bigs" Griselbrand, Avacyn, Angel of Hope, Gisela, Blade of Goldnight
"Combo Kills" Progenitus, Emrakul, the Aeons Torn, Blightsteel Colossus

These dozen-odd creatures just about obsolete most other creatures for the purposes of 'High End Finisher'. Color Restrictions Not Applying, if you're looking for a Giant Stick, these are probably what you're looking at. If you're looking for something else, you're setting yourself Color Restrictions or trying to win more Fast and Consistent than these because you don't have the combo pieces or are restricting yourself from combo to do something more interesting/fun, if slow, ineffecient, and less effective.

The only two I can think of that are actually in still in this League?

Akroma, Angel of Wrath and Phage, the Untouchable.

Phage needs a Mythic Reprint. Period.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Aggro_Red
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
I have to say, she is by far and long, my favorite Magic card. I really think people don't give this card enough credit. While its true that she can, in many many ways, be the one that kills YOU and not your opponent, she EMBODIES Black Magic. She fits, whole and true, the 'kill or be killed' concept of Black. The 'win at ANY cost' that used to be so prominent in Black cards. She also instills a sort of nervouseness in players if they don't have that immediate answer, and must sacrifice all they have built to keep her away until they can be rid of her.

Functionally, the card is, as many have noted, very difficult to use. But its exactly why she is so much fun to play. Experienced players bash her with unrelenting malice, calling her a 'noob card'. Any card that can give you a potential auto win deserves such a major drawback. Its BLACK.

Phage has always had a great effect on games in my playgroup. We are not, by any means, pros. We play casual, and we often play EDH. And its so much fun to slap her down and to see them look painfully at their hands, wondering if they need to waste precious counter, removal, or burn to be rid of her. Yes, she can turn on you if you try to Cheatyface her into play. Yes, she can kill you if she is flickered. But she can also kill your opponent with the many ways to make her unblockable.

Its justifiable that she can easily one shot YOU as she can your foe. A creature with her power needn't feel THREATENED by you, anymore than your foe.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Enelysios
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Well I am currently making a Phage the untouchable EDH deck because all my friends joke about how she is the worst general. I have always loved her, this card just feels so perfectly, evilly black. WHen you have her out, someone is losing, either you or your opponent. The deck is coming along nicely too. Obviously Torpor Orb, Platinum Angel and Sundial of the infinite are in, so I can play her. I enjoy the fact that these combos have the potential to lose me the game if they fail too. Dying by your own general is just neat.

The rest of the deck will be pretty standard mono-black control, but I want to keep with the theme of her, so lots of boardwipes, of course the unblockable enablers, and an Akroma's Memorial for irony/fun. This will be my forth mono black EDH (Ashling the extinguisher, Endrek Sahr, Master Breeder and a retired griselbrand deck) and undoubtably my worst, but I am looking forward to some fun games.

Me: "Alright, and while I calculate the damage, care to read the card again?"

Lifegain deck: "....WHAT?"

Blue Control deck: "That's AWESOME! GIMME THAT! *Casts clone on Phage*

Me: "Alright, and maybe you want to read her as well?"

Blue Control deck: "....WHAT?"

Me: "I believe that's game ladies and gentlemen."

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: MisterAction
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Not only does this perfectly represent everything about black (extreme power with a risk attached), it's my new favorite card.

Not because it's good (and it is good), but because of how it makes people feel. When Phage comes out, everyone's nervous, but at the same time they're excitedly scheming on how to turn her against her caster. And boy are there so many ways to do this (target her with Banisher Priest, kill her and cast Living Death, give her persist or undying, or just steal her and swing in). It's not just some weird corner case; Phage will nearly always end the game, but you truly can never know exactly which way she'll swing. And when she does one-hit-kill your opponent, the game's done; I'd always rather be killed by her than some stupid drawn-out Erayo lock.

And just knowing she's in your opponent's deck is intimidating. Do you really want to cast that It That Betrays? That Telemin Performance? That Rise of the Dark Realms? Choices are more interesting when Phage is around.

Plenty of other cards are better, but a lot of good cards just crush your opponent's spirit. Nothing else quite excites the imagination like Phage the Untouchable.

106427: Phage the Untouchable.author: Paleopaladin
106427: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
EDIT / UPDATE: I was wrong -- Karn Liberated's rulings clarify that restarting the game after exiling her means that you *DO* lose:

"After the pre-game procedure is complete, but before the new game's first turn, Karn's ability finishes resolving and the cards left in exile are put onto the battlefield. If this causes any triggered abilities to trigger, those abilities are put onto the stack at the beginning of the first upkeep step."
_________________________________________________________
She's cool, but I'm afraid of a card that lets a single Otherworldly Journey kill me.

BTW, Karn Liberated's ultimate works with her since she never "enters the battlefield" in that case.

106428: Forbidding Watchtower.author: Palochka
106428: Forbidding Watchtower.text_parsed:
Braid_of_Fire's Card of the Day #4

Definitely not the strongest of the cycle, but very white, perhaps even to a fault. With all of the other man-lands in the bunch, they were there to sweep up the game post-wrath or when your threats just weren't staying on the board. This land can survive more than its brethren at the cost of almost never being used to get in there for extra damage. It certainly ruins your opponent's combat math, which is probably good enough for a CIPT land in your average 60-card mono-white pick-up deck (which, even with three modifiers, is one of the most common types of Magic decks in existence).

I saw the Xth edition printing of the card before being treated to the Urza's art, and I was amazed. This was the kind of land that would inspire me as a planeswalker and opened up a whole new kind of card. The art is as immediate as a land can be and the effect provokes an image of soldiers defending you as the last line after all of your other creatures are passed by. Sure, it prevents you from drawing mana from the land, but its utility is its greatest feature. The Urza's art does not present this same "battlefield" view, the kind of view that makes it feel like you're playing something more than a card came, but it balances out this emotion with one of Vorthosian satisfaction by nature of being situated on Serra's plane. I still prefer the Xth edition art, but I can appreciate all those who swear by the old frame and the iconic floating plains of the original.

106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.author: sonorhC
106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.text_parsed: @magicrocks, I don't think it would quite work with Confusion in the Ranks the way you're describing. The first Squee would go off as you say and give you a creature, but the second Squee would die before the exchange could take place, and exchanges need both targets to be valid or they don't take effect. So you'd only steal one creature per two castings of Squee, not two.
106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.text_posted: @magicrocks, I don't think it would quite work with [autocard]Confusion in the Ranks[/autocard] the way you're describing.  The first Squee would go off as you say and give you a creature, but the second Squee would die before the exchange could take place, and exchanges need both targets to be valid or they don't take effect.  So you'd only steal one creature per two castings of Squee, not two.

loyalty = 1

106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.author: JaxsonBateman
106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.text_parsed:
Such a good card... so good that it can easily be run in decks that don't have the slightest intention of running any red mana sources. I've been running at least one copy in virtually all my decks with Fauna Shaman, and for good reason - her ability effectively becomes G, T: tutor a creature every turn. You can keep playing out the creatures you find and keep on digging with her, seeing as Squee keeps coming back to your hand.

@Mattscz - the issue with the skeleton is twofold. Firstly, it requires 2 mana to bring it back. Secondly, it goes to the battlefield, when Squee is used for a lot of "discard a card" hijinx, like Fauna Shaman, Chandra Ablaze, Mind Over Matter, etc. Reassembling Skeleton is better if you want multiple sacrifices, but then, Gravecrawler is even better than that.
106473: Squee, Goblin Nabob.text_posted:

106525: Ascendant Evincar.author: RJTheDestroyer
106525: Ascendant Evincar.text_parsed:
The only way it isn't is if you're playing against another Black deck. I pulled this guy out, my opponent had three 1/1 green creatures out (one of them from getting two -1/-1 counters on it from Sickle Ripper) and a 2/1 guy, so they all died when he came into play and he was left with two weakened creatures against my 4 or 5 creatures that were all beefed up from this guy. Plus, he has flying which helps (and your opponent basically can't pull out any 1/1 non-black creatures or they'll just die when they hit play).

He does cost quite a bit, but can help you win some games, so I'll give him a 4/5.

106537: Platinum Angel.author: allmighty_abacus
106537: Platinum Angel.text_parsed:
You people are absolutely crazy. Let me just drop a few random quotes from the comments, show you how stupid you sound.


"Allows you to punch other players, steal their cards, and blatantly cheat. No judge can give you a match loss."
I'm pretty certain if you PHYSICALLY ATTACK somebody you'll still be disqualified. Hell, you might even be arrested depending on how out of hand you get. Have fun explaining to your cellmate Bubba that you got arrested for being a total douchebag at a card game.

"I think it's hands-down the best card ever made!"
Come on, seriously? Maybe in bizarro world where cards like oh the power nine don't exist.

"No other card protects you as well."
Hiding behind your cards is the game of amateurs and doomed cowards. And in any case, there are far better cards to protect you. Moment's Peace or any of the other fog effects can completely negate an alpha strike, and leave your opponent wide open for a brutal counter attack. A properly-casted Batwing Brume could even result in an unexpected victory. But regardless, the best defense is an aggresive and calculated offense. Not losing =/= winning

All the angel does is guarantee your opponent will save up to four kill spells for this guy. This is the most overrated card ever printed. Especially bad in multiplayer, because after one of your many enemies gets rid of it, everyone gangs up on you for wasting a slot on such a gimmicky card.

Completely overrated, beyond gimmicky and too much mana to waste on a 4/4 flier.

Anyway, this + Mycosynth Lattice = no lands for anyone. Great if you have a deck that builds itself (perhaps through tokens).

Ael - Strickly speaking, an artifact is a permanant, and thus only in play. However it doesn't differentiate. Wizards and grammar aren't on the best of terms, but "permanant noncreature artifact" would clear up any confusion.
Common sense states that just because something is a card, and not a permanant, doesn't stop it being an artifact. I live in NZ, but if I moved, I'd still be human (at least I'd hope so).

106555: March of the Machines.text_posted:
Does this ability apply to artifacts that are not on the field (in the hand or in the deck, for example) as well?

106555: March of the Machines.author: OmegaSerris
106555: March of the Machines.text_parsed:
@Angelbaka
No, neither case would the ability be in effect. When it doesn't say "card" or "spell", it is assumed to be a permanent. So to affect artifacts in your hand, library, graveyard, and (I believe) exiled zone, it has to say "noncreature artifact card". And for the stack, it would have to say "noncreature artifact spell". So unless it is in play, this ability does not affect them at all. See Painter's Servant and Mycosynth Lattice for an example of what I mean.

On the other hand, this does make them a creature as they enter the battlefield. Much like how lords (Creatures that improve other creatures of the same time) increase power/toughness as a creature enters the battlefield. So noncreature artifacts WILL trigger "When a creature enters the battlefield..." abilities with this out there.

I put 3 of these in my deck and on average I lose 1 life per land per game, making them on par with the $10 duals for the first 3-of. Except I can't run 4 or then I might get stuck with nothing else and lose a lot more life.

129480: Crucible of Worlds.author: Nighthawk42
129480: Crucible of Worlds.text_parsed:
Aside from hosing land destruction and combos when able to play multiple lands in a turn (Fastbond, Oracle of Mul Daya, etc.), this is amazing with landfall and fetch lands. Would have been a power card in Standard if it had stayed in for M10 and still may be good in Extended.

This plus Lotus Cobra plus Terramorphic Expanse = 2 mana of any color and a new land (comes in tapped) every turn.

This plus a Rampaging Baloth and Terramorphic Expanse = 2 new 4/4's and a new land (tapped) every turn.

If you have the Baloth and the Cobra you get both. With fetch lands the new land comes in untapped at a cost of 1 life...maybe even better although it adds up if you're doing it every turn.

129480: Crucible of Worlds.author: DoctorKenneth
129480: Crucible of Worlds.text_parsed:
This also negates Countryside Crusher's drawback. Which, you know. Is nice. Not as breaking as the infinite combos, of course, but there it is.

Also, lest we forget, this Johnny-gasm is brought to us by the community itself- it is the happy product of You Make the Card 2, back when Wizards trusted us with card design. I guess the fact that we kept making combo pieces (Forgotten Ancient was also one) sort of put them off the idea. Still, none of them every really got to see much play, so it's really a shame we don't get a few more cracks at it.
129480: Crucible of Worlds.text_posted:
This also negates [autocard]Countryside Crusher[/autocard]'s drawback. Which, you know. Is nice. Not as breaking as the infinite combos, of course, but there it is.

Also, lest we forget, this Johnny-gasm is brought to us by the community itself- it is the happy product of You Make the Card 2, back when Wizards trusted us with card design. I guess the fact that we kept making combo pieces ([autocard]Forgotten Ancient[/autocard] was also one) sort of put them off the idea. Still, none of them every really got to see much play, so it's really a shame we don't get a few more cracks at it.

129480: Crucible of Worlds.author: Mirrordin_Pure
129480: Crucible of Worlds.text_parsed:
Even back when I was just beginning and first saw this card, I knew it had power...I still never truly understood its uses though.

Now, after years of playing, I see fully why this card is deserving of its rating and more. Playing it after an Armageddon or popping Ajani Vengeant in my boros weenie EDH can be a devastating push ahead for myself, has won me more games than I can recall, and that's just one use!

Use it to recur fetch lands, Evolving Wilds , Terramorphic Expanse, any land that requires sacing as a cost. I had a friend use it with two Flagstones of Trokair to pull out plains after plains onto the field and race ahead of me.

Marit Lage die after saccing Dark Depths ? Sure, there's other, more interesting ways to recur it that can bring back your Hexmage and your land, but the point is this can do it too!

How bout those Manlands? Want a guy who just won't stay dead? Well Now you've got one!

And I'm sure Goblin Trenches will thank you as well.

Truly, this is an amazing card; I love it to death and I'm sure even still that the surface hasn't even been scratched towards the knowing of its full potential.

5/5 from me.

129480: Crucible of Worlds.author: Ferlord
129480: Crucible of Worlds.text_parsed:
This + Zuran Orb + Fastbond + F**k ban lists = infinite life-gain.

Sacrifice a land to Zuran Orb: gain 2 life.

Play the land thanks to Crucible. It will cost 1 life because of Fastbond.

Repeat.

Infinite tokens can happen if Rampaging Baloths are out. Infinite mana can happen if Lotus Cobra is out. Quick milling can happen if Hedron Crab is out. The same can occur with Scrib Nibblers. Did I say something about Searing Blaze dealing infinite damage? I TOTALLY DID NOT EDIT IT OUT BECAUSE I WAS AN IDIOT BEFORE!

Add anything with landfall to this combo, and you break the game.

129494: Boomerang.author: AMart83
129494: Boomerang.text_parsed:
Rating: 5/5 as far as bounce spells go.

For me, it's really between this, Into the Roil, and Banishing Knack.

Banishing Knack :
-Good:
--Cheapest of all bounces, letting you play another spell or two
--Unsuspecting if you're opponent doesn't play you for having a 1 mana blue spell
--Combos with untapping abilities
-Bad:
--Requires a creature (a control deck might not like this)
--That creature is susceptible to removal/burn/bounce, getting you 2-for-1'd, failing to bounce your intended target
--It can't go after lands (whether your opponents or one of your own if playing against LD)
--It can't go after Planeswalkers

Into the Roil :
-Good:
--Cheaper and easier to cast than Boomerang in a multi-colored deck
--Flexible
--Cantrips
--A good card in the early game and the mid-late game
-Bad:
--If it's kicked and your opponent manages to make the target illegal, you don't get to bounce the intended target, you don't draw a card, and you tapped out 4 mana for nothing
--It can't go after lands
--It can't go after Planeswalkers

Boomerang :
-Good:
-Goes after lands. If you play 2 in a row in the early game while hitting your land drops, your opp. might not be able to catch up before it's too late.
--Goes after Planeswalkers
-Bad:
--Not very splashable

129497: Caves of Koilos.author: Hovercraft
129497: Caves of Koilos.text_parsed: This is a better top-deck than Marsh Flats at least. I think it still warrants some consideration if you're able to play a deck with many splashable cards you might never need to take more than 1 or 2 damage since it is a painless land for 1 colorless mana. In a fast legacy game i think it amounts to about the same. If you top deck a fetch you have to take the loss of life to get any use from the land. Technically you could turn the damage from the pain into an advantage through gaining life but it is awkward I guess. You could also prevent the damage.. but really it is not so easy. Play this with artifacts like Cursed Scroll and equipment and you'll get better use out of it you'll find yourself tapping these for the colorless more often than you might think.

129497: Caves of Koilos.author: Kryptnyt
129497: Caves of Koilos.text_parsed:
"This is a better top-deck than Marsh Flats at least."
You mean when you're playing against aggro and you're at 1 life?
Otherwise, even if a player is at 2 life or 3, getting two lands out of your deck with one draw is great, and shuffles are hyper-important in Legacy and EDH nowadays because of Brainstorm type abilities.
I'd say this is a good land though. Base set duals and shocklands are often considered better because of their land type, but it's not so strange to want some land after someone casts Flashfires.

129497: Caves of Koilos.author: DoragonShinzui
129497: Caves of Koilos.text_parsed:
This isn't actually strictly worse than Marsh Flats. This remains flexible constantly, while Marsh Flats has to make a commitment to the mana it brings in. This can be tapped for colorless if you don't feel like paying life, while Marsh Flats always requires the life to convert to the land you "need." Marsh Flats needs either a Swamp or Plains to fine, while this doesn't. And the Caves only use up one slot, while Marsh Flats are useless without something to grab.

While I agree that Marsh Flats may be more useful a lot of the time, especially with landfall, the Caves are in the colors of life stealing. That one damage isn't going to matter much when you're stealing it all back.

129501: Clone.author: jceddy
129501: Clone.text_parsed:
Question about kicked cards: if clone copies a card that was kicked, then does it get the kicked stats? Or can you kick the clone as you're casting it? Or neither? The way the rules on this read as follows:

706.2. When copying an object, the copy acquires the copiable values of the original objects characteristics and, for an object on the stack, choices made when casting or activating it (mode, targets, the value of X, whether it was kicked, how it will affect multiple targets, and so on).

This sounds like it's saying that you get the kicked stats only if you could somehow cast clone while the other creature is still on the stack? Am I reading that correctly?
129501: Clone.text_posted:
Question about kicked cards: if clone copies a card that was kicked, then does it get the kicked stats? Or can you kick the clone as you're casting it? Or neither? The way the rules on this read as follows:

706.2. When copying an object, the copy acquires the copiable values of the original objects characteristics and, for an object on the stack, choices made when casting or activating it (mode, targets, the value of X, whether it was kicked, how it will affect multiple targets, and so on). 

This sounds like it's saying that you get the kicked stats only if you could somehow cast clone while the other creature is still on the stack? Am I reading that correctly?

What about if you have Dregscape Zombie (creature type zombie) a Shivan Zombie (which is creature type barbarian zombie), and Balduvian Barbarian (which is creature type Human Barbarian).

What creatures get what bonuses?

I think the Dregscape would get +1/+1, the Shivan Zombie +2/+2, and the Balduvian Barbarian would get +1/+1.

A friend thinks the Dregscape Zombie would get +1/+1, the Shivan Zombie +1/+1, and the Balduvian Barbarian would get nothing.

We went back and forth on this for ages. His friend tried saying "actually, none of them get any bonuses at all, since they are 3 different creature types. We interjected of course, with the card text example, and he stopped talking.

129512: Creeping Mold.author: Yukikah
129512: Creeping Mold.text_parsed:
Personally, between this and Bramblecrush, I'd say it's a tie. If they were both in standard at the moment it would be Bramblecrush easily. But looking at vintage/legacy/commander, they're pretty equal.

There are almost 11 times as many artifact creatures to choose from as planeswalkers at the moment, you see. Combine this with most artifact creatures being splashable thanks to being colorless (and being better in multiples even with the M14 changes), and you're much more likely to have an artifact creature to cast this on than a planeswalker.

And, as a side note, this can also hit lands that happen to be creatures as well. Not a ton of those of course, but the ones that are out there certainly see play. So not a non-factor as it were.
129512: Creeping Mold.text_posted:
Personally, between this and Bramblecrush, I'd say it's a tie.  If they were both in standard at the moment it would be Bramblecrush easily.  But looking at vintage/legacy/commander, they're pretty equal.

Combine this with most artifact creatures being splashable thanks to being colorless (and being better in multiples even with the M14 changes), and you're much more likely to have an artifact creature to cast this on than a planeswalker.

And, as a side note, this can also hit lands that happen to be creatures as well.  Not a ton of those of course, but the ones that are out there certainly see play.  So not a non-factor as it were.

129514: Cruel Edict.author: Tanaka348
129514: Cruel Edict.text_parsed:
I find it interesting that even though this card is solid, it's also in most cases generally worse than three other cards, but none of those three others are outright broken. I guess we can go with an edict roll call:

Cruel Edict: Specifies opponent, which means it can't be Swerved back at you.
Diabolic Edict: Instant speed
Chainer's Edict: Has flashback, albeit at an extremely high cost ()
Warren Weirding: Can be pointed at yourself to turn one Goblin into two, with Rogue powers if you're into that. But your opponent has the same choice, and even though against your average Goblin deck Edicts are pretty worthless anyway, there's still a chance your opponent is running some one-off goblins like Boros Recruit.
129514: Cruel Edict.text_posted:
I find it interesting that even though this card is solid, it's also in most cases generally worse than three other cards, but none of those three others are outright broken. I guess we can go with an edict roll call:

[autocard]Cruel Edict[/autocard]: Specifies opponent, which means it can't be [autocard]Swerve[/autocard]d back at you.
[autocard]Diabolic Edict[/autocard]: Instant speed
[autocard]Chainer's Edict[/autocard]: Has flashback, albeit at an extremely high cost ([5][B][B])
[autocard]Warren Weirding[/autocard]: Can be pointed at yourself to turn one Goblin into two, with Rogue powers if you're into that. But your opponent has the same choice, and even though against your average Goblin deck Edicts are pretty worthless anyway, there's still a chance your opponent is running some one-off goblins like [autocard]Boros Recruit[/autocard].

129521: Dehydration.author: NoobOfLore
129521: Dehydration.text_parsed:
Dehydration doesn't tap the card.

It only keeps it from untapping naturally.

I feel as though this is just a tad overcosted, anyways.

Could probably pass for 3 mana, seeing as it doesn't stop abilities that don't require tapping, static abilities, they can still be untapped by other means, and it hardly slows down creatures with vigilance.

129526: Pithing Needle.author: omniszron
129526: Pithing Needle.text_parsed:
@DocCid
An activated ability is easy to recognize. It has a formatting that goes somewhat like this - "cost: effect". For example "Tap, pay 2R: Do something". Thus an ability describing a creature's power or i.e.: First Strike or Flying are NOT activated abilities, thus unaffected by Pithing Needle's ability.
129526: Pithing Needle.text_posted:
@DocCid
An activated ability is easy to recognize. It has a formatting that goes somewhat like this - "cost: effect". For example  "Tap, pay 2R: Do something". Thus an ability describing a creature's power or i.e.: First Strike or Flying are NOT activated abilities, thus unaffected by Pithing Needle's ability.

129526: Pithing Needle.author: Vadoff
129526: Pithing Needle.text_parsed:
@DocCid: You're correct, it's a static ability and cannot be affected by Pithing Needle. An activated ability is very easy to spot, it's simply anything with a colon ":". If it doesn't have a colon, then it's not an activated ability!
Ex. Sacrifice a creature: do X, Tap: do X, Lose 1 life: do X, pay RRR: do X
129526: Pithing Needle.text_posted:
@DocCid: You're correct, it's a static ability and cannot be affected by Pithing Needle. An activated ability is very easy to spot, it's simply anything with a colon ":". If it doesn't have a colon, then it's not an activated ability!

129526: Pithing Needle.author: DacenOctavio
129526: Pithing Needle.text_parsed: This is roughly how Yawgmoth betrayed and incapacitated poor, gullible Dyfed, the Dominarian planeswalker who took him to the artificial, 8-layered metallic plane that would become the Phyrexian homeworld. When Dyfed was mercifully slain during the Thran rebellion, Yawgmoth had her dissected and her tissues cataloged for future study. Presumably, such processing led to the development of artificial planeswalking technology used by the Phyrexians to infiltrate plane after plane.

129527: Dragon's Claw.author: A3Kitsune
129527: Dragon's Claw.text_parsed: This cycle has become a standard part of core sets, replacing the previous cycle of life-gain artifacts (Wooden Sphere et all).
129527: Dragon's Claw.text_posted: This cycle has become a standard part of core sets, replacing the previous cycle of life-gain artifacts ([autocard]Wooden Sphere[/autocard] et all).

129527: Dragon's Claw.author: Baconradar
129527: Dragon's Claw.text_parsed:
It's interesting that even with such a major power up of the previous cycle of life gain cards, their purpose remains exactly the same: these are skill testing cards which are designed to appeal to newer players for their obvious synergy, but are actually very low power.

The dragon's claw is definitely the best of the cycle, because it can actually be used against red burn decks fairly successfully and because red has quite a few spells which can be cast over and over again, like glitterfang.

129529: Drudge Skeletons.author: aegis_magi
129529: Drudge Skeletons.text_parsed:
The only thing this card has going for it is flavor, and there it really shines. Nothing says undead like a skeleton that won't stay down.

Playability is a different issue. It is over costed as a 1/1, and it's ability is a total man sink. In order for this to be of value on the battlefield, you must accept being one or more mana down from a tempo basis.

In the end this card simply has too high of an opportunity cost.

In a world of creature power creep, it's surprising that drudge skeletons is still a decent card.

129535: Elvish Piper.author: humor_love
129535: Elvish Piper.text_parsed:
Regarding the Myojin of Life's Web question:

To pay Myojin's casting cost and put it onto the battlefield is to 'play' it.

To use Elvish Piper is to 'put' it onto the battlefield.

One process is 'playing' a spell. The other process is 'putting' a card.
129535: Elvish Piper.text_posted:
Regarding the [autocard]Myojin of Life's Web[/autocard] question:

To pay Myojin's casting cost and put it onto the battlefield is to 'play' it.

To use Elvish Piper is to 'put' it onto the battlefield.

One process is 'playing' a spell. The other process is 'putting' a card.

129536: Llanowar Sentinel.author: tcollins
129536: Llanowar Sentinel.text_parsed:
This is an exquisite ability in green, as some have mentioned it is somewhat similar to the kicker ability. In reality it's actually quite a bit better, when you pay the kicker cost on a card, you do so when it is cast, with Llanowar Sentinel you pay the optional cost when it enters the battlefield, the difference? If you're playing against a blue mage, they would have to decide to counter the spell before you decided whether or not to pay for the effect, since the spell needs to resolve first. Also if you have lots of mana open, you can fetch more than one.

{2}{G} = 1 Llanowar Sentinel
{3}{G}{G} = 2 Llanowar Sentinel
{4}{G}{G}{G} = 3 Llanowar Sentinel
{5}{G}{G}{G}{G} = 4 Llanowar Sentinel

129536: Llanowar Sentinel.author: ICEFANG13
129536: Llanowar Sentinel.text_parsed:
No this does not work like multikicker at all. Multikicker is an activated ability that can be used when the spell is cast. This is a triggered ability, you can tell by the wording.

When this happens you may do this (Check)

When it comes into play, so when this happens, you can keep reading, when you do this you may do this, it seems pretty straightforward to me.

When it comes into play, when you have done this, you may pay 1G, blah.

"602.1. Activated abilities have a cost and an effect. They are written as "Cost: Effect. Activation instructions (if any).""

This is not an activated ability, it doesn't have a cost, the ":" is very critical to identify it.

Hum, "603.1. Triggered abilities have a trigger condition and an effect. They are written as "Trigger condition, effect," and begin with the word "when," "whenever," or "at." They can also be expressed as "When/Whenever/At trigger event, effect.""

Seems like a triggered ability doesn't it?

"603.2c An ability triggers only once each time its trigger event occurs. However, it can trigger repeatedly if one event contains multiple occurrences. See also rule 509.4.
Example: A permanent has an ability whose trigger condition reads, "Whenever a land is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, . . . ." If someone casts a spell that destroys all lands, the ability will trigger once for each land put into the graveyard during the spell's resolution."

So when it enters, if you pay 1G, then this effect happens, it can only happen once per Llanowar Sentinel that comes into play.

129541: Evacuation.author: leomistico
129541: Evacuation.text_parsed:
Like Kontrah said, the blue board sweep! I think that blue needs a little more this kind of mass bounce... If they reprint Day of Judgment every year, they could actually reprint this without fear! (accidentally I put it in rhyme...) The fact that it's an instant makes it an unpleasant surprise... However I would like it even if it were a sorcery that costs {2UU}, but it would lose 50% of its blue-ness...

I remember one game I played some years ago, when facing a red deck that had a Shivan Dragon in the battlefield. My opponent attacked me, I hadn't anything to defend. "I take... How many dmg?" I said taking the pen in the hand ready to write my life points. So my opponent, thinking that I haven't anything to stop the dragon, pumped it at its max without fear, so in response I played Evacuation. It was a little upset, but it was a funny match nonetheless!

5/5

I would say "Reprint, please!" but I play almost modern, so it's not a problem, only that I'd like to see more mass-bounce effects in blue.

129546: Festering Goblin.author: CXA26483
129546: Festering Goblin.text_parsed:
Personally, as an avid Zombie fan, I don't believe ~ belongs in a Zombie deck. If you want a one drop in Zombies, I would go with Carrion Feeder due to it's ability to shut off Graveborn Muse, and protect your other 'bies from things like Path to Exile or Oblivion Ring (seeing as how a Zombie in your graveyard can be easily returned via Lord of the Undead or Unholy Grotto).

HOWEVER, in a budget deck, I love ~. It can kill 2/2s, and easily synergizes with other commons (like Carrion Feeder), making it a very versatile turn 1 or turn 0 drop. In a deck, your creature's deaths are usually not a problem, as your usually the one killing everything anyways.

129546: Festering Goblin.author: Misago
129546: Festering Goblin.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.0) Festering Goblin can be an early game attacker while having the potential to become a pesky 1/1 creature's nightmare. By itself, the Festering Goblin is able to take out a 2/2 creature or finish off a creature granting an extra -1/-1. Because the ability does not do damage, Festering Goblin can get rid of small regenerators like Drudge Skeletons or Will-o'-the-Wisp. One drawback to this card is that the triggered ability is not optional. In other words, if your opponent has no creatures, he can destroy Festering Goblin in order to kill two of yours! In my black/red casual goblin deck, I try not to run goblins with a toughness of 1 that will be susceptible to this gruesome tactic, such as: Knucklebone Witch, Goblin Chirurgeon, etc. Even with the new change in rules from M10, Festering Goblin still is not as effecient as the "all so famous" Mogg Fanatic. The main reason for this is that Festering Goblin requires another card or action to occur, such as death in combat, for the -1/-1 effect to take place. On top of that, Festering Goblin cannot be used to deal 1 damage directly to the opponent like the Fanatic can. If you are running red in your deck, use the slightly better version of this card: Goblin Arsonist. (Posted By: Misago)

129546: Festering Goblin.author: Silverware
129546: Festering Goblin.text_parsed:
I have a love for Zombie tribal, I have played with almost every zombie in MTG and Festering Goblin is one of my personal favorites in mono-black zombie aggro as a solid 1 drop. While I agree with CXA26483 that Carrion Feeder is a great card in its own right, I feel that Festering Goblin fits most Zombie tribal just as well, Festering Goblin is amazing in that when it is comboed with cards like Fleshbag Marauder you may often get a 2 for 1 deal where you destroy two of their creatures for the price of one, and trade your 1/1 in for a 3/1.

Basicly it can trade with a 2/2 right from the start, kill 1/1s with firststrike and snipe off mana excel creatures like birds of paradise, and llanowar elves. While the argument can be made if this card is truely better for zombies since carrion feeder can stop creatures from being exiled, thus making them easier to recover I feel that in most cases you are going to be playing FAST, and most of the time it won't matter if one or two zombies are exiled, especialy since with path to exile your carrion feeder would actully deprive you of the land you would get. If you really need to stop a creature from being exiled you can always respond by using nameless inversion on your own creature. But wouldn't it just be better to use your spell to kill someone elses creature instead of keeping one or two of your creatures from being exiled? Exactely, this is the very argument I use for the Festering Goblin vs. Carrion Feeder debate.

As an additional note, in many games Carrion Feeder's ability becomes much less favorable when cards such as leyline of the void, wheel of sun and moon, Tormod's Crypt,and Bojuka Bog poke up their heads.

I understand that both cards have their merits, If you are going to play mostly zombies with a high cmc that you need to be able to recover from your graveyard then Carrion Feeder may be the better choice,or maybe even outside of zombies with cards like Reas-sembling Skeleton.

129553: Shimmering Wings.author: SleetFox
129553: Shimmering Wings.text_parsed:
They needed to timeshift this to white. I have a white enchantment recursion deck and I would have loved to have 4 of these. This and Flickering Ward are the only enchantments that can be played and returned for 2 mana. Unfortunately, every Island is a land that can't be used for Flickering Ward, and every Plains is a land that can't be used for Flickering Ward. Outside of spending 200 dollars on duel lands...

White can screw with enchantment plays more than blue, so this card is kind of obsolete as a replayable enchantment. It's still decent for its "intended" purpose if you don't have a lot of flyers, especially in a Simic-colored deck. You can keep it in your hand and take your opponent by surprise with which creature you give wings when you attack or block, and then return it afterward.

129553: Shimmering Wings.author: Dabok
129553: Shimmering Wings.text_parsed:
I like to compare this to Phantom Wings.
This costs only 1.
It is recurrent flying, since you bounce it when your creature dies, pretty much like a paid Rancor.
So it's a pretty solid effect, if you insist on your creatures having flying (like in a ninja deck for example).
You can also bounce this if you have a bigger threat on board that you want to grant flying.
-
Phantom Wings on the other hand is more versatile.
It costs 2.
You can use it to grant your creature flying and the ability to dodge death once (via bounce).
Or you can use it to Unsummon the enemy creature at sorcery speed.
-
I think I'm going to vouch for Phantom Wings for the general usefulness. Even in a ninja deck where you want your creatures to have flying, this is because I value "removal evasion" so much, though.
Still, a pretty good card.
3.5/5

129553: Shimmering Wings.author: lokterrorgar
129553: Shimmering Wings.text_parsed:
All I want to do is combo this with any of the "Heroic" cards from Theros. It would be INSANE in casual. In particular I combo this with Agent of the Fates and I can usually clear the board for 6 mana (albeit they HAVE to be blue mana), but that works out to be ridiculously cheap considering the result and at the end of it I have a 3/2 flier with deathtouch.

Giving this card a solid 5/5 just because it absolutely breaks in half when it pairs up with Heroic.

129557: Wild Griffin.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
129557: Wild Griffin.text_parsed:
Pretty average. It's practically a vanilla creature. And there are many cards which are probably better than it, including Diving Griffin. But it's cute and works pretty well in my casual deck, so I'm happy with it. The art by Matt Cavotta is great. The flavor is great. I like the 10th edition one better because of the art and the flavor text, which is specially lulzy when put besides Griffin Rider.
I have a casual Griffin White Weenie deck (2 of this, 4 Diving Griffins, 4 Griffin Sentinels, 4Griffin Riders, 4 Guardians' Pledges which I'd replace with Honor of the pure if I weren't too cheap buy them, 4 Pacifisms and some Elite Vanguards and White Knights to round it up) and this works well in it.
In sum, I like it mostly for art and flavor, even though Diving Griffin is much better.

Saying that this is worse than deathtouch is not true at all. Deathtouch requires that you damage the target, so this card negates any danger of damage redirection or healing. This is actually closer to the "original" death touch that was around in the days of revised:

Venom
Thicket Basilisk

She obviously isn't super powerful, but what you're really getting is a creature that is either a) going to wipe out something guaranteed as long as you have the mana or b) going to do 2 points of damage, before any other buffs are added.

Definitely not bad, 3.5/5

129574: Knight of Dusk.author: GrimjawxRULES
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_parsed:
To Raptorman333 - you're wrong. The Knight won't deal damage to the defending player after you've killed the blockers with its ability. That's because the Knight is still considered to be blocked, but since the creatures it was blocked by no longer exists, the Knight won't deal its damage to anything.
(to explain - the Knight tries to deal damage to its blockers, but since they're no longer on the battlefield, the damage is automatically prevented by the game rules)

Another example is Sylvan Basilisk - if it kills its blockers, it still won't deal any damage to the defending player, because it was blocked.


I can see why the Knight is good, but must say that the ability is quite expensive, considering the cost of the knight itself. Sure, I can see the cool thing in having an attacking 2/2 creature on your 4th turn that no one wants to block, but that's about it. Even if your opponents should block the Knight, you should consider the fact that there are better ways of spending your 4th turn than destroying a single creature (your opponent would be stupid to block with 2) and start your second main phase with 2 mana open and a tapped 2/2 creature.

To repeat Gaussgoat's last line - "Definitely not bad, 3.5/5"

129574: Knight of Dusk.author: DeathDark
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_parsed:
@Grimjaw

Nay.

If we look at how this is playing out, first you declare attackers, then your opponent declares blockers. After blockers are declared, wiping out a blocker with Unsummon, Doom Blade, Path to Exile, or any other such card, causes the creature to no longer be blocked.

After all, how are you going to be blocked by something that isn't there?

I give this card a 4.5. In my hands, I can pump it up to levels where blocking it would be nice, but obviously un-doable. I have quite a few black creatures that just fly through and prick the enemy to death, such as Dread Warlock. Though it may seem inefficient, it keeps them on a time limit (at least 10 turns, not counting other creatures).

129574: Knight of Dusk.author: achilleselbow
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_parsed: @Deathdark: Please go look up the official rules; few things in Magic work the way you would think just through logical reasoning :-) Once blockers are declared, that's it - any creatures that are blocked stay blocked, no matter what happens afterwards. In the examples you cite, you could unsummon, exile, or otherwise remove a blocking creature with an instant right after you declare attackers, BEFORE the opponent can declare blockers. But you can't do that with this Knight's ability because it requires the creature to already be blocking the Knight in order to be targeted. And once that happens, he is already blocked until end of combat. If you just think of the Knight's ability as some sort of super first strike, it will make more sense to you.
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_posted: @Deathdark: Please go look up the official rules; few things in Magic work the way you would think just through logical reasoning :-) Once blockers are declared, that's it - any creatures that are blocked stay blocked, no matter what happens afterwards. In the examples you cite, you could unsummon, exile, or otherwise remove a blocking creature with an instant right after you declare attackers, BEFORE the opponent can declare blockers. But you can't do that with this Knight's ability because it requires the creature to already be blocking the Knight in order to be targeted. And once that happens, he is already blocked until end of combat. If you just think of the Knight's ability as some sort of super first strike, it will make more sense to you.

129574: Knight of Dusk.author: Leo...Preliator
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_parsed:
The official rules


509.1h An attacking creature with one or more creatures declared as blockers for it becomes a blocked creature; one with no creatures declared as blockers for it becomes an unblocked creature. This remains unchanged until the creature is removed from combat, an effect says that it becomes blocked or unblocked, or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. A creature remains blocked even if all the creatures blocking it are removed from combat.

510.1c A blocked creature assigns its combat damage to the creatures blocking it. If no creatures are currently blocking it (if, for example, they were destroyed or removed from combat), it assigns no combat damage.
129574: Knight of Dusk.text_posted:
The official rules


[i]509.1h An attacking creature with one or more creatures declared as blockers for it becomes a blocked creature; one with no creatures declared as blockers for it becomes an unblocked creature. This remains unchanged until the creature is removed from combat, an effect says that it becomes blocked or unblocked, or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. A creature remains blocked even if all the creatures blocking it are removed from combat.[/i]

[i]510.1c A blocked creature assigns its combat damage to the creatures blocking it. If no creatures are currently blocking it (if, for example, they were destroyed or removed from combat), it assigns no combat damage.[/i]

I think what people fail to realize is that, when the creature(s) is destroyed, there is nothing left blocking her, so not only is she going to automatically deal 2 damage to the player, but also wipe out the defending player's troops. throw an unholy strength or any pump card on this *** and you have a nearly unblockable beast to wield. it just further exemplifies black's motif of creature destruction. Certainly better than Severed Legion.

EDIT: Wow, when I posted this comment, 3/9/2010 7:27:15 AM, I had a great misconception of the rules. With the correction, my rating agrees with Gaussgoat, as well. I can think of several other things for 3 mana that I'd rather play (i.e. if I were looking for creature destruction, I'd rather use royal assassin for the cost), but would certainly consider putting this in my Chainer EDH deck with Nightmare Lash and Strata Scythe.

129577: Spark Elemental.author: mdakw576
129577: Spark Elemental.text_parsed:
ball lightning's little brother. However, it's rather weak. Compare to, say, lava spike...

- This is a weak draw lategame, since by then your opponent is bound to have a creature tough enough to block this. Lava spike can still hit for 3 damage. I guess if you really wanted to, you play this, swing, your opponent blocks with a fattie, and then you follow up with a bolt or something to kill it, but that's a 2 for 1 in your opponent's favor, so that's probably not a good idea unless you're behind.
- It's harder to deal with lava spike. This dies to first strike creatures or pingers like prodigal pyromancer. Lava spike only has to worry about things like damage prevention or counters, which spark elemental has to worry about anyway.

129583: Grave Pact.author: Misago
129583: Grave Pact.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.0) Grave Pact is always a pleasure to play in a multiplayer format. If your oponent's do not have an answer for an enchantment in thier hand, any strategy they have involving even the most sturdy of creatures (i.e. Progenitus) will be fruitless. In light of the hefty 3 black mana required to cast it, Grave Pact is a rather difficult card to splash. Because having more than one in your hand equates to a dead card, Grave Pact makes my list of superb "one of's". Since you will be already running black, I recommend Demonic Tutor and Vampiric Tutor to make it seem like you are running three in your deck. If you are on a budget, Diabolic Tutor will suffice. In my favorite casual black/red goblin deck, I run 1 Grave Pact along with... 4 Mogg War Marshal, 2 Goblin Chirurgeon, 2 Skirk Prospector, and 1 Tuktuk the Explorer to ensure fodder plus an instance speed FREE sac. engine. I also run 1 Goblin Warrens to 99% ensure an opponent will NOT have a creature on the board! A Phyrexian Tower also works well to supply the sacrifice engine and black mana needed. On a side note, the artwork for the 8th edition version is fantastic. Check it out! (Posted By: Misago)
129583: Grave Pact.text_posted: (Card Rating: [b][u]4.0[/u][/b]) Grave Pact is always a pleasure to play in a multiplayer format. 129583: Grave Pact.author: Gabriel422
129583: Grave Pact.text_parsed: Grave Pact was fair in the tournament sense - it appeared as a sideboard tech in some tier-2 Zombie decks. But just play one / have one played against you in semi-casual, even, and it suddenly becomes the most unfair card ever. As long as the Grave Pact deck is filled with enough copies of things like Rotlung Reaminator, Spawning Pit, Pawn of Umalog and the like, the enchantment basically reads: Destroy all creatures you don't control, and destroy each creature you don't control as it enters the battlefield. It spelt game over against too many decks, while at the same time leaving you with a weak deck (with all the token creatures) when you don't draw it. Fair in the win-percentage sense, sure, as the tournaments showed... but still, that is pretty much the recipe of unfun games.

129583: Grave Pact.author: infernox10
129583: Grave Pact.text_parsed:
Consider black's massive amount of sacrifice for the sake of powerful effects, or costs for powerful permanents.
This card will affect the game the instant it hits the field.
Your opponent will become reluctant to block.
Your opponent will become reluctant to attack.
Your opponent will be reluctant to use removal (except exiling, of course).
Your opponent will use removal to get rid of this card, if he or she can.
This card is extremely powerful, and could never be in any other colour.
This fits black's theme crazily well:
"This is going to hurt me, but it'll hurt you far more."

129588: Guerrilla Tactics.author: MacBizzle
129588: Guerrilla Tactics.text_parsed:
This card is phenomenal with Chain of Plasma, Chain of Smog and Scandalmonger in a madness styled deck. Yes, the copy of Chain of Plasma that the opponent copied "causes" you, though it may not be mandatory, to discard a card. Chain of Smog and Scandalmonger are a little more obvious. The opponent copied the spell/activated the ability, so the source is under their control.

The problem with this deck is trying to tempt people to use your spells against you. More often than not, Chain of Plasma winds up being a Volcanic Hammer by the second game, after they saw your trickery in the first game. And unfortunately, Mindslaver would seem like a waste if you were simply trying to make yourself discard. If you don't mind building a deck that you can efficiently run only once, go for it. Put in blue for Psychic Purge and some possible Quickens, of course.
